Problem:
Consider a system modeled by the function \\( z(t) = Ce^{i\omega t} \\) which is a complex exponential representing oscillatory behavior with a constant \\( C \\) and angular frequency \\( \omega \). An operator \\( T \\) acts on \\( z(t) \\) as follows: \\( Tz(t) = z(t + h) \\), where \\( h \\) is a time-shift constant.

If an additional operator \\( U \\) defined by \\( Uz(t) = z(t - k) \\) (where \\( k \\) is a constant time-shift) is applied as an intervention at t = \\( t_1 \\), will the final state of \\( z(T) \\) for T > \\( t_1 \\) and T > k depend only on \\( \omega \\) and not on \\( h \\) or \\( k \\)?
Explanation: The application of \\( U \\) adds an opposing time-shift effect, thereby further modifying the trajectory of the system along with the earlier time-shift by \\( T \\). Thus, the final state at time T depends on both time shifts (\\( h \\) and \\( k \\)), as well as the underlying frequency \\( \omega \\), leading to a complex interplay of shift interactions.
